document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) schah Abeille de Perrin, 1904 species-group, with description of two new species from Iran (Coleoptera: Buprestidae: Anthaxiini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) schah Abeille de Perrin, 1904 species-group, with description of two new species from Iran (Coleoptera: Buprestidae: Anthaxiini)

Taxonomic notes . Although
Obenberger ( 1940 )
did not specify the number of specimens he had examined, the description of
Anthaxia ( H. ) wethloi
was certainly based on more than one specimen, since he gave a range of dimensions of 4 to 5 mm . More particularly, the fact that he wrote of a last ventrite not notched, means that he was describing a male specimen. In the Obenberger collection are conserved five syntypes of this species, all with the same data, three of which are males. In order to establish a single name-bearing type for this species, I designate the male specimen with extracted genitalia ( NMPC inv. 22146 ) as lectotype , and the remaining four specimens as paralectotypes ( 2 ♀♀ inv. 22147 /22148, 1♂ inv. 22149, 1♂ without inv. nr.).

In his description, Obenberger compared this species to
A. ( H. ) semiramis Obenberger, 1913
, actually a very similar species from northern Syria belonging to the
A. ( H. ) angustipennis
species-group, from which
A. ( H. ) wethloi
can be readily distinguished by the shape of male genitalia and of the protrochanters.

Bionomy and distribution .
Anthaxia ( H. ) wethloi
is a strongly polyphagous species and its larva develops in a wide range of Angiosperms. It has been reared from
Acer
sp. ( Aceraceae ),
Astragalus
sp. ( Fabaceae ),
Ficus
sp. ( Moraceae ),
Pistacia
sp. ( Anacardiaceae ),
Prunus
sp. ( Rosaceae ),
Rosa
sp. ( Rosaceae ) and
Salix
sp. ( Salicaceae ) (all first hostplant records). The adults are flower-visitors and are active from April to June.

This species was described from the Bushir province, and is currently considered endemic to Iran . It is mainly found in rather hot and arid biotopes, from the southeastern part of the Zagros range to most of the central and eastern Iranian provinces. Apparently, there are no records from the southern coastal area where it seems to be widely replaced by
A. ( H. ) iveta Svoboda, 2003
a species developing in
Acacia
( Fabaceae ) and
Ziziphus
( Rhamnaceae ) (both first hostplant records). Records from eastern Syria , northeastern Iraq and Caucasus ( Bílý 1997 , 2006 ) though possible, need confirmation (Bílý pers. com.).
